awd_titl_txt: New Frameworks for Ethical Research Amidst Emerging Digital Technologies, Algorithms, and Privacy Norms
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers across fields--including biomedical, behavioral, cognitive, educational, computer, information, and social sciences--use digital technologies recruit human participants, develop interventions, collect and analyze data, and disseminate findings. The technologies include mobile phones, wearable computing, body sensors, tracking apps, and social networking platforms. Artificial intelligence and other algorithms are embedded in the technologies. Algorithms and models grow, along with personal information that people provide, bringing personalized experiences to daily activities, such as shopping, reading news articles, and watching movies. People’s perceptions about the privacy of their personal information likewise evolve. The growth of such technologies gives researchers access to more research participants and expanded opportunities to study complex human behaviors unobtrusively, in real-time. However, using these digital technologies to conduct research requires new core concepts of research ethics, such as informed consent, autonomy, and confidentiality. This project will investigate new ethical frameworks for protecting human research participants in response to the digital age and develop resources for the scientific community and the public. Outcomes will be broadly disseminated to faculty researchers, research staff, students and the community through informational videos, webinars, informational brochures, and guidelines for training platforms. Content will be served through the American Psychological Association’s website, podcasts, blogs, and social media. 

The project will support working group activities and a public conference for stimulating computing ethics research addressing: (1) How do current ethical, legal/regulatory, or social issues, either in degree or kind, address (or not address) the use of digital technologies in human research? (2) How have people’s perceptions on sharing personal information changed with the ubiquitous use of digital technologies, and how will this affect the use of digital technology in human research? (3) How has the ubiquitous use of algorithms, including AI, in everyday digital technologies, impacted ethical dimensions of human research? (4) What ethical frameworks can address emerging uses of digital technologies when conducting research with human participants with a variety of technology literacy characteristics and privacy perceptions? The project is expected to generate the following outcomes: (1) white papers outlining ethical, legal, and social issues related to the use of electronic and mobile technologies in research; (2) a set of training guidelines for students and researchers on the conduct of research using such technologies, to be disseminated to regulatory organizations, professional societies and universities; (3) design requirements of training and educational tools; and (4) research plan for a follow-up proposal to evaluate, improve, and support the training agenda.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Within one year, the award produced several outcomes:

  • A publication
  • Three short reports
  • A public-facing seminar
  • A public workshop
  • As recipients of the NSF Award, PI (Huh-Yoo) and Co-PI (Panicker) were invited to serve as co-editors of a special issue of the American Psychologist focused on research ethics in the digital age. (Slated for publication Jan 2024)

The award brought together eight experts in diverse disciplines, including philosophy, science and technology studies, bioethics, psychology, computer science, and information science, as part of three working groups who investigated answers to the following three questions:

  1. How has the ubiquitous use of digital technologies (including technologies that involve artificial intelligence/machine learning) impacted the ethical dimensions of human research?
  2. Does the prevailing ethical framework for research with human participants, as elucidated in the Belmont Report?
  3. What is the proper ethical framework for addressing the uses of digital technologies when conducting research with human participants with a wide range of technology literacy?

The resulting reports generated knowledge on existing gaps in the capacities of ethical frameworks in thinking about ethics of research with human subjects in the digital era. The working groups proposed solutions to identified challenges which included using  existing resources as well as developing newer tools and solutions to address those challenges. 

 

The award allowed us to hold a public-facing webinar that attracted over 700 attendees, primarily research ethics and regulatory oversight professionals from academic institutions as well as non-profit and for-profit organizations. This webinar was the prelude to a 6-hour interactive workshop that featured presentations from invited six speakers, including Mary L. Gray, Microsoft Research, Desmond Upton Patton, University of Pennsylvania, Jonathan Herington, University of Rochester, Barbara Barry, Mayo Clinic, Jonathan Beever, University of South Florida, and Joshua August Skorburg, University of Guelph. The sessions were moderated by Dena Plemmon, University of California Riverside and Elisa Hurley, PRIM&R. Both the speakers as well as over 700 individuals who participated in the workshop shared a common interest in exploring ethical frameworks to address the traditional as well as emerging issues in a rapidly evolving research landscape that is deeply impacted by the ubiquity of digital technologies in research as well as in everyday life.

This publicly available recorded webinar as well as workshop continue to be used as teaching and training tools.. The resulting ideas and questions continue to be explored within classrooms, including graduate programs in the computing field. Students are asked to brainstorm how existing frameworks address (or do not) the challenges they see in the rapidly evolving technological landscape and working with human subjects in their studies. 

This award produced several unpublished and published reports, and more drafts are being produced for publication. The award also fostered collaborative conversations among interdisciplinary researchers. Lastly, PRIM&R is continuing work on the issue and is exploring the feasibility of convening a multi-stakeholder coalition to gauge the need for an updated ethical framework for the conduct of research with human subjects.
